description: First attested 1581, borrowed from French diatribe, from Latin diatriba (“learned discussion or discourse”), from Ancient Greek διατριβή (diatribḗ, “way of spending time, lecture”), from διά (diá, “through”) + τρίβω (tríbō, “I waste, wear out”)

entries.meaning: An abusive, bitter verbal or written attack, criticism or denunciation.
examples: The senator was prone to diatribes which could go on for more than an hour.

entries.meaning: A prolonged discourse; a long-winded speech.
